title: The Physics of a Cricket Ball
summary: How swing bowling, spin, and batting use Newton's Laws and fluid dynamics.
content:
Case Study: Cricket Ball Physics

Cricket is India's most popular sport, and the physics behind it is fascinating! From a fast bowler's swing to a spinner's turn, physics is always in play.

Swing Bowling

A cricket ball has a seam. When bowled with the seam at an angle and one side polished, air flows differently on the two sides — creating a pressure difference (Bernoulli's Principle) that curves the ball in the air.

Batting and Momentum

When a batsman hits the ball, momentum is transferred. A straight drive follows projectile motion — the ball travels in a parabolic arc. The timing of the follow-through increases impulse, maximising distance.

Spin Bowling

A spinner puts backspin or topspin on the ball. This creates a Magnus effect — the rotating ball deflects due to pressure differences around it, causing it to dip or curve after bouncing.

Key Formulas

  • Momentum: p = mv
  • Impulse: J = FΔt = Δp
  • Projectile range: R = v²sin(2θ)/g
